editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it hath been sundry times acted by the children of Paul's.
At London, ‚ùß printed for A. I. and are to be sold at the sign of the white horse in Paul's churchyard. An. 1607.

div.head: Inductio.
div.stage: Enter Michaelmas term in a whitish cloak, new come up out of the country, a boy bringing his gown after him!

sp.speaker: Micha:
sp.p: Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Here sit!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Lay by my conscience, give me my gown,
That weed is for the country,
We must be civil now, and match out evil,
Who first made civil, black; he pleased the devil;
So; now know I where I am, methinks already
I grasp best part of the Autumnian blessing
In my contentious fathom, my hand's free,
From wronger and from wronged I have fee,
And what by sweat from the rough earth they draw,
Is to enrich this silver harvest, law,
And so through wealthy variance, and fat brawl,
The barn is made but steward to the hall;
Come they up thick enough?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: O like hops and harlot's sir!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: Why dost thou couple them?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: O very aptly, for as the hop well boiled will make a man not stand upon his legs: so the harlot in time will leave a man no legs to stand upon!

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Such another and be my heir, I have no child,
yet have I wealth would redeem beggary,
I think it be a curse both here and foreign,
Where bags are fruiful'st, there the womb's most barren,
The poor has all our children, we their wealth;
Shall I be prodigal when my life cools,
Make those my heirs whom I have beggared; fools?
It would be wondrous; rather beggar more,
Thou shalt have heirs enough, thou keepest a whore,
And here comes kindred too with no mean purses,
Yet strive to be still blessed with client's curses.

div.stage: Music playing. Enter the other 3. Termes, the first bringing in a fellow poor, which the other 2. advanceth, giving him rich apparel, apage, and a pandar. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: What subtlety have we here? A fellow
Shrugging for life's kind benefits, shift and heat,
Crept up in 3. Terms, wrapped in silk and silver,
So well appointed too with page and Pandar,
It was a happy gale that blew him hither.

list.item: 1. Thou father of the terms hail to thee.
2. May much contention still keep with thee.
3. Many new fools come up and fee thee.
2. Let 'em pay dear enough that see thee.

lg.l: And like asses use such men,
When their load's off, turn 'em to graze again.
And may our wish have full effect, many a suit, and much neglect.
And as it hath been often found, let the client's cups come round.
Help your poor kinsmen when you ha' got 'em. You may drink deep, leave us the bottom;
Or when there is a lamb fallen in, take you the lamb, leave us the skin.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: Your duty and regard hath moved us,
Never till now we thought you loved us,
take comfort from our words, and make no doubt,
You shall have suits come sixteen times about.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We humbly thank the patron of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.l: With what a vassal ‚Äî appetite they gnaw,
On our reversions; and are proud,
Coldly to taste our meats, which eight returns
Serve in to us as courses;
One day our writs like wildfowl fly abroad,
And then return o'er cities, towns, and hills,
With clients like dried straws between their bills;
And 'tis no few birds pick to build their nests,
Nor no small money that keeps drabs and feasts!

div.p: But gentlemen, to spread myself open unto you, in cheaper terms I salute you, for ours have but sixpenny fees all the year long, yet we dispatch you in two hours, without demur; your suits hang not long here after candles be lighted: why we call this play by such a dear and chargeable title, Michaelmas term? Know it consents happily to our purpose, though perhaps faintly to the interpretation of many; for he that expects any great quarrels in law to be handled here, will be fondly deceived, this only presents those familiar accidents, which happened in town in the circumference of those six weeks, whereof Michaelmas term is lord: sat sapienti, I hope there's no fools i'th house!
div.stage: Enter at one door master Rerrage, meeting master Salewood.

sp.speaker: Salewood:
sp.p: What master Rerage?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Master Salewood ‚ñ™ exceedingly well met in town, comes your father up this term?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why he was here three days before the exchequer gaped.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fie, such an early termer?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
He's not to be spoke withal, I dare not ask him
blessing, till the last of November.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And how looks thy little venturing cousin?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Faith like a lute that has all the strings broke, nobody will meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Fie, there are doctors enough in town will string her again, and make her sound as sweet as ere she did, is she not married yet?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: She as no luck, some may better steal a horse than others look on. I have known a virgin of five bastards wedded, faith when all's done we must be fain to marry her into the North I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: But will she pass so think you?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Puh, any thing that is warm enough is good enough for them; so it come in the likeness, though the devil be in't, they'll venture the firing.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: They're worthy spirits i'faith, heard you the news?

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Mistress difficult is fallen a widow.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Say true, is master difficult the lawyer dead?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Easily dead sir.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Pray when died he?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What a question's that? when should a lawyer die but in the vacation, he has no leisure to die in the termtime, beside the noise there would fetch him again.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: Knew you the nature of his disease.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith some say he died of an old grief he had, that the vacation was fourteen weeks long.

sp.speaker: Sal:
sp.p: And very likely. I knew 'twould kill him at last, t'as troubled him a long time, he was one of those that would fain have brought in the heresy of a fifth term, often crying with a loud voice, o why should we lose Bartholmew week?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He savours, stop your nose, no more of him.

div.stage: Enter master Cockstone, a gentleman meeting master easye of Essex.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Young master easy, let me salute you sir, when came you?

sp.speaker: Easy:
sp.p: I have but inned my horse since master Cockstone.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: You seldom visit London master easy,
But now your father's dead 'tis your only course,
Here's gallants of all sizes, of all lasts,
Here you may fit your foot, make choice of those
Whom your affection may rejoice in:

sp.speaker: Easy:
sp.l: You have easily possessed me I am free,
Let those live hinds that know not liberty.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Master Rerage?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Good master Salewood, I am proud of your society.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: What gentleman might that be?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: One master Esay, has good ‚óènd in Essex,
A fair free-breasted gentleman, somewhat too open,
Bad in man, worse in woman,
The gentry-fault at first, he is yet fresh
And wants the city powdering, but what news?
Is't yet a match twixt master Qomodo's the rich draper's
Daughter and yourself.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Faith sir, I am vildly rivaled!

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Vildly? by whom.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: One Andrew Lethe crept to a little warmth, and now so proud that he forgets all storms, one that ne'er wore apparel, but like ditches 'twas cast before he had it, now shines bright in rich embroideries, him master Quomodo affects, the daughter him, the mother only me, I rest most doubtful, my side being wookest.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Yet the mother's side being surer than the fathers, it may prove, men plead for money best, women for love.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: 'Slid master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: How then, afraid of a woollen draper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: He warned me his house, and I hate he should see me abroad!

div.stage: Quomodo with his two spirits, Shortyard and Falselight.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: O my 2. spirits Shortyard and Falselight, you that have so enriched me, I have industry for you both?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Then do you please us best sir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Wealthy employment.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: You make me itch sir.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: You Falselight as I have directed you.

sp.speaker: Fals:
sp.p: I am nimble.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Go, make my course commodities, look, seek, with subtle art beguile the honest eye, be near to my trapwindow, cunning Falselight.

sp.speaker: Fals:
sp.p: I never failed it yet.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: I know thou didst not;
But now to thee my true and secret Shortyard,
Whom I dare trust e'en with my wife,
Thou ne'er didst mistress harm, but master, good,
There are too few of thy name gentlemen,
And that we feel, but citizens' abundance,
I have a task for thee my pregnant spirit,
To exercise thy pointed wits upon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Give it me, for I thirst.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.l: Thine care shall drink it,
Know then I have not spent this long vacation
Only for pleasure's sake, give me the man
Who out of recreation culls advantage,
Dives into seasons, never walks, but thinks,
Ne‚óèides, but plots, my journey was towards Essex.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Most true?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Where I have seen what I desire.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: A woman?

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Puh; a woman, yet beneath her, that which she often treads on. Yet commands her land, fair neat land.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: What is the mark you shoot at.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Why the fairest to cleave the heir in twain, I mean his title to murder his estate, stifle his right in some some detested prison, there are means and ways enough to hook in gentry, besides our deadly enmity which thus stands they're busy about our wives, we about their lands.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.l: Your revenge is more glorious,
To be a cuckold is but for one life,
When land remains to you, your heir, or wife!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Ah sirrah, do we sting 'em, this fresh gallant road newly up before me!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I beseech his name.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Young master easy.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Easy? It may fall right.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: I have enquired his haunt, stay, ha, I that, 'tis, that's he, that's he!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Happily!

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: Observe, take surely note of him, he's fresh and free shift thyself speedily into the shape of gallantry, I'll swell thy purse with angels, keep foot by foot with him, outdare his expenses, flatter, dice, and brothel to him, give him a sweet taste of sensuality, train him to every wasteful sin, that he may quickly need health, but especially money, ravish him with a dame or two, be his bawd for once, I'll be thine for ever, drink drunk with him, creep into bed to him, kiss him and undo him, my sweet spirit.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Let your care dwell in me soon shall it shine, what subtlety is in man, that is not mine.

sp.speaker: Quo:
sp.p: O my most cheerful spirit, go, dispatch, gentry is the chief fish we tradesmen catch.

sp.speaker: Easy:
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: O, they are bills for chambers.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Against saint Andrew's, at a painter's house, there's a fair chamber ready furnished to be let, the house not only endowed with a new fashion forepart, but which is more convenient for a gentleman, with a very provident backdoor.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why here's virtue still; I like that thing that's necessary, as well as pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: What news in yonder paper.

sp.speaker: Rerra:
sp.p: Ha? seek you for news, there's for you!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Whose 'tis? in the name of the black angels, Andro Gruill.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No, Andro Lethe!

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Lethe?

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Has forgotten his father's name, poor Walter Gruill that begotten him, fed him, and brought him up.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not hither.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: No; 'twas from his thoughts, he brought him up below.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: But does he pass for Lethe.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Amongst strange eyes that no more know him, than he knows himself, that's nothing now, for master Andro Lethe, a gentleman of most received parts, forgetfulness, lust, impudence, and falsehood, and one especial courtly quality; to wit, no wit at all, I am his rival for Quomodo's daughter, but he knows it not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Has spied us o'er his paper.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: O that's a warning to make our duties ready.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Salute him, hang him.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Puh, wish his health a while, he'll be laid shortly, let him gorge venison for a time, our doctors will bring him to dry mutton; seem respective to make his pride swell like a toad with dew.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Master Lethe!

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Sweet master Lethe.

sp.speaker: Lathe:
sp.p: Gentlemen your pardon, I remember you not.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Why we supped with you last night sir!

sp.speaker: Lethe:
sp.l: O cry you mercy, 'tis so long ago,
I had quite forgotten you, I must be forgiven,
Acquaintance, dear society, suits and things,
Do so flow to me; that had I not the better memory!
'Twould be a wonder I should know myself,
Esteem is made of such a dizzy mettle;
I have received of many gifts o'er night
Whom I have forgotten ere morning, meeting the men,
I wished 'em to remember me again,
They do so: then if I forget again,
I know what helped before, that will help then,
This is my course, for memory I have been told
Twenty preserves, the best I find is gold;
Ay truly! are you not knights yet, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Not yet!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: No, that must be looked into, 'tis your own salt,
I have some store of venison, where shall we devour it,
Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.l: The horn were a fit place.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: For venison, fit,
The horn having chaste it,
At the horn ‚Äî we'll rhyme to that. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.p: Taste it.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Wast it.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Cast it.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: That's the true rhyme indeed, we hunt our venison
Twice I tell you, first out a'th park, next out a'th belly.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: First dogs take pains to make it fit for men,
Than men take pain to make it fit for dogs.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Cock:
sp.l: Why this is kindness, a kind gallant, you,
and love to give the dogs more than their due,
We shall attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I pray do so.

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: The horn.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Easily remembered that you know!

div.p:
But now unto my present business, the daughter yields, and Quomodo consents, only my mistress Quomodo, her mother without regard runs full against me, and sticks hard! Is there no law for a woman that will run upon a man at her own apperil. Why should not she consent, knowing my state, my sudden fortunes, I can command a custard, and other bake-meats, death of sturgeon, I could keep house with nothing, what friends have I? how well am I beloved, e'en quite throughout the scullery, not consent? 'tis e'en as I have writ, I'll be hanged, and she love me not herself and would rather preserve me, as a private friend to her own pleasures, than any way advance her daughter upon me to beguile herself, then how have I relieved her in that point, let me peruse this letter. Good mistress Quomodo, or rather as I hope ere the term end, mother Quomodo, since only your consent keeps a loof off and hinders the copulation of your daughter, what may I think, but that it is a mere affection in you, doting upon some small inferior virtue of mine, to draw me in upon yourself, if the case stand so, I have comfort for you: for this you may well assure yourself, that by the marriage of your daughter I have the better means and opportunity to yourself, and without the least suspicion. This is moving stuff, and that works best with a citizen's wife, but who shall I get to convey this now: my page I ha' sent forth, my pandar I have employed about the country, to look out some third sister, or entice some discontented gentlewoman from her husband, whom the laying out of my appetite shall maintain, nay I'll deal like an honourable gentleman, I'll be kind to women, that which I gather i'th day, I'll put into their purses at night, you shall have no cause to rail at me, no faith, I'll keep you in good fashion ladies, no meaner men than knights shall ransom home your gowns, and recover your smocks, I'll not dally with you ‚Äî some poor widow woman would come as a necessary bawd now: and see where fitly comes ‚Äî my mother! curse off
poverty does she come up to shame me, to betray my birth, and cast soil upon my new suit, let her pass me, I'll take no notice of her, scurvy ‚Äî murrey ‚Äî Carsey!

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: By your leave and like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Then I must proudly venture it; to me good woman.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: I beseech one word with your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Prithee be brief then.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: Pray can your worship tell me any tidings of one Andro Gruill, a poor son of mine own.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: I know a gallant gentleman of the name, one master Andro Gruill and well received amongst ladies.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: That not he then!
He is no gentleman that I mean.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Good woman if he be a Gruill, he's a gentleman i'th mornings: that's a gentleman a'th first, you cannot tell me

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: No truly, his father was an honest upright tooth-drawer.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: O my teeth.

sp.speaker: Moth:
sp.p: An't please your worship, I have made a fore journey out, all this vacant time, to come up and see my son Andro, poor Walter Gruill his father has laid his life, and left me a lone woman, I have not one husband in all the world, therefore my coming up is for relief an't like your worship, hoping that my son Andro is in some place about the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Kitchen, puh, fah.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Or a servingman to some knight of worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: O let me not endure her! Know you not me good woman?

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alas, an't please your worship, I never saw such a glorious suit since the hour I was kirsened.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.l: Good, she knows me not, my glory does disquiet me,
Beside my poorer name being drenched in Lethe,
She'll hardly understand me, what a fresh air can do!
I may employ her as a private drudge,
To pass my letters and secure my lust,
And ne'er be noted mine, to shame my blood,
and drop my staining birth upon my raiment, faith good
Woman you will hardly get to the speech of master Andro,
I tell you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: No?
Marry hang him, and like your worship, I have known the day when nobody cared to speak to him!

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You must take heed how you speak ill of him now I cantle you; he's so employed.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Employed for what?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: For his behaviour, wisdom, and other virtues.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: His virtues? no 'tis well known, his father was too poor a man to bring him up to any virtues; he can scarce write and read.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: He's the better regarded for that amongst courtiers, for that's but a needy quality!

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: If it be so, than he'll be great shortly, for he has no good parts about him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Well good woman, or mother, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Alack the day, I know your worship scorns to call me mother: 'tis not a thing fit for your worship indeed, such a simple old woman as I am.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: In pity of thy long journey, there's sixpence British: tend upon me, I have business for you.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: I'll wait upon your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: Two pole off at least.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: I am a clean old woman, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: It goes not by cleanness here good woman, if you were fouler, so you were braver, you might come nearer.

sp.speaker: Mo:
sp.p: Nay and that be the fashion, I hope I shall(Exit.get it shortly, there's no woman so old but she may learn; and as an old lady delights in a young page or monkey, so there are young courtiers will be hungry upon an old woman, I warrant you.

div.stage: Enter Lethe's pandar with a country wench.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Come, leave your puling and sighing.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Beshrew you now, why did you entice me from my father

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p:
Why? to thy better advancement, wouldst thou a pretty
beautiful ‚Äî juicy squall, live in a poor thrummed house i'th country in such servile ‚Äî habiliments, and may well pass for a gentlewoman i'th city, does not 5 hundred do so thinkst thou, and with worse faces, o, now in these latter days, the devil reigning 'tis an age for cloven creatures? but why sad now? yet indeed 'tis the fashion of any courtesan to be sea-sick i'th first voyage, but at next she proclaims open wars, like a beaten soldier: why Northamptonshire lass dost dream of virginity now? remember a loose-bodied gown wench, and let it go, wires, and tires, bents and bums, felts and falls, thou that shalt deceive the world, that gentlewomen indeed shall not be known from others; I have a master to whom I must prefer thee, after the aforesaid decking, Lethe by name, a man of one most admired property, he can both love thee and for thy better advancement be thy pandar himself, an exc'llent spark of humility.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: Well heaven forgive you, you train me up to't.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Why I do acknowledge it, and I think I do you a pleasure in't.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: And if I should prove a harlot now, I should be bound to curse you.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Bound? nay and you prove a harlot, you'll be loose enough.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: If I had not a desire to go like a gentlewoman, you should be hanged, ere you should get me to't I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Nay that's certain, nor a 1000. more of you, I know, you are all chaste enough, till one thing or other tempt you‚óè deny a satin gown and you dare now?

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: You know I have no power to do't, and that makes you so wilful: for what woman is there such a beast that will deny any thing that is good.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: True they will not, most dissembler.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: No, and she bear a brave mind she will not I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: Why, therefore take heart, faint not at all,
Women ne'er rise, but when they fall,
Let a man break, he's gone, blown up,
A woman's breaking sets her up,
Virginity is no city ‚Äî trade,
You're out a'th freedom, when you're a maid,
down with the lattice 'tis but thin,
Let courser beauties work within:
Whom the light mocks, thou art fair and fresh,
The guilded flies, will light upon thy flesh.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.l: Beshrew your sweet enchantments, you have won.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: How easily soft women are undone:
So farewell wholesome weeds where treasure pants,
And welcome silks, where lies disease and wants:
Come wench, now flow thy fortunes in to bless thee,
I'll bring thee where thou shalt be taught to dress thee!

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: O as soon as may be, I am in a swoon till I be a gentlewoman, and you know what flesh is man's meat, tell it be dressed.

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.p: Most certain, no more a woman.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter Rerrage, Salewood, Lethe, easye, with Shortyard alias Blastfield, at dice.

sp.speaker: Rer:
sp.p: Gentlemen I ha' sworn I'll change the room: dice?

sp.speaker: Leth:
sp.p: You see I'm patient gentlemen ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Sale:
sp.p: Ay, the fiends in't, you're patient, you put up all. Devils.

sp.speaker: Rer ‚ñ™
sp.p: Come set me gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: An Essex gentleman sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: An unfortunate one sir.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: Indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: He's second to my bosom.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I'll give you that comfort then sir, you must not want money as long as you are in town sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No sir?

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I am bound in my love to him to see you furnished, and in that comfort I recover my salute again sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Then I desire to be more dear unto you.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: I rather study to be dear unto you ‚Äî boy, fill some wine. ‚Äî I knew not what fair impressure I received, at first, but I began to affect your society very speedily.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I count myself the happier.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: To master Alsup sir, to whose remembrance, I could love to drink till I were passed remembrance.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I shall keep Christmas with him sit, where your health shall likewise undoubtedly be remembered, and thereupon I pledge you: ‚Äî I would sue for your name sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Your suit shall end in one term sir: my name is Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Kind master Blastfield, your dearer acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Nay come, will ye draw in gentlemen? set me:

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Faith I'm scattered.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Sir, you shall not give out so meanly of yourself in my company for a million: make such privy to your disgrace? you're a gentleman of fair fortunes; keep me your reputation; set 'em all, there's crowns for you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Sir you bind me infinitely in these courtesies.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You must always have a care of your reputation here in town master Easie, although you ride down with nothing, it skills not.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'm glad you tell me that yet, then i', e indifferent. Well, come: who throws? I set all these.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, well said.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: This same master Lethe here begins to undo us again.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ah sir, I came not hither but to win.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And than you'll leave us, that's your fashion.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: He's base that visits not his friends:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: But he's more base that carries out his winnings.
None will do so but those have base beginnings

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: It is a thing in use and ever was, I pass this time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I wonder you should pass. And that you're suffered.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Tut, the dice are ours,
Then wonder not at those that have most powers ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: The devil and his angels.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Are these they? Welcome dear angels, where you're cursed ne'er stay.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Here's luck.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Let's search him gentlemen, I think he wears a smock:

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I knew the time, he wore not half a shirt, just like a pea.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No, how did he for the rest?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Faith he compounded with a couple of napkins at Barnet, and so truss up the lower parts.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Twas a pretty shift i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But master Lethe has forgotten that too.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: A mischief on't to lose all: I could ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay but good ma Easie, do not do yourself that tyranny I beseech you, I must not ha' you alter your body now for the purge of a little money: you undo me and you do.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Twas all I brought up with me, I protest master Blastfield, all my rent till next quarter.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Pox of money, talk not on't I beseech you, what said I to you? Mass I am out of cash myself too, ‚Äî boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Run presently to master Gum the mercer, and will him to tell out two or three hundred pound for me, or more according as he is furnished: I'll visit him ith' morning say.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It shall be said sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Do you hear boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If master Gum be not sufficiently ready, call upon master profit the goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I know I was not sent yet now is the time.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let them both rest till another occasion: you shall not need to run so far at this time, take one nigher hand go to ma. Quomodo the draper, and will him to furnish me instantly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Now I go sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: It seems you're well known master Blastfield, and your credit very spacious here ith' city.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Master Easie, let a man bear himself portly, the whoresons will creep to him a'th their bellies, and their wiues a'th their backs: there's a kind of bold grace expected throughout all the parts of a gentleman: then for your observances, a man must not so much as spit but within line and fashion. I tell you what I ha' done: sometimes I carry my water all London over, only to deliver it proudly at the standard, and do I pass altogether unnoted think you? No, a man can no sooner peep out his head, but there's a bow bent at him out of
some watch tower, or other.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: So readily sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Push, you know a bow's quickly ready, though a gun belong a charging, and will shoot five times to his once, come, you shall bear yourself jovially: take heed of setting your looks to your losses, but rather smile upon your ill luck, and invite 'em tomorrow to another breakfast of bones.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay I'll forswear dicing.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? peace? I am ashamed to hear you: will you cease in the first loss, show me one gentleman that ere did it? Fie upon't I must use you to company I perceive, you'd be spoiled else: forswear dice? I would your friends heard you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay I was but in jest sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I hope so, what would gentlemen say of you? there goes a gull that keeps his money, I would not have such a report go on you, for the world as long as you are in my company. Why man fortune alters in a minute, I ha' known those have recovered so much in an hour, their purses were never sick after.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: O worse than consumption of the liver! consumption of the patrimony.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? mark their humours master Easie.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Forgive me, my posterity, yet ungotten.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's a penitent maudlin dicer.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Few know the sweets that the plain life allows. Vild son that surfeits of his father's brows.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Laugh at him master easy.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I'll be damned and these be not the bones of some quean that cozened me in her life, and now consumes me after her death.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's the true-wicked-blasphemous, and soul-shuddering dicer, that will curse you all service time, and attribute his ill luck always to one drab or other.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Dick, Hell-gill: the happy news.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I have her for you sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Peace, what is she?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Young, beautiful and plump. ‚Äî a delicate piece of sin.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Of what parentage?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: O a gentlewoman of a great house.

sp.speaker: Leh.
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: She newly came out of a barn; yet too good for a tooth-drawer's son.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Is she wife or maid?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: That which is daintiest, maid

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I'd rather she'd been a wife.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: A wife sir, why?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O adultery is a great deal sweeter in my mind.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Diseases gnaw thy bones. I think she has deserved to be a wife sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: That will move well.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Her firstling shall be mine. Swine look but for the husks, the meat be thine.

sp.speaker: Sho:
sp.p: How now boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master Quomodo takes your worship's greeting exceeding kindly, and in his commendations returns this answer, that your worship shall not be so apt to receive it, as he willing to lend it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why, we thank him i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Troth, and you ha' reason to thank him sir, was a very friendly answer.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Push, a gentleman that keeps his days even here ith' city (As I myself watch to do) shall have many of those answers in a twelvemonth, master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I promise you sir I admire your carriage, and begin to hold a more reverend respect of you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not so I beseech you, I give my friends leave to be inward with me, ‚Äî will you walk gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: We're for you. Present her with this jewel my first token.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: There are certain countrymen without enquiring for master Rerage, and master Salewood.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Tenants!

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: Thou revivest us rascal.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: When's our next meeting gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: Tomorrow night, this gentleman, by me invites you all, do you not master Easie?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Freely sir.

sp.speaker: Salew.
sp.p: We do embrace your love ‚Äî a pure fresh gull

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Thus make you men at parting dutiful, and rest beholding to you, 'tis the slight to be remembered, when you're out of sight.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: A pretty virtue.

div.stage: Enter the countrie-wenches father, that was enticed for Leth:

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Where shall I seek her now? ‚Äî o if she knew the dangers that attend on women's lives, she would rather lodge under a poor thatched roof then under carved seelings: she was my joy, and all content that I received from life, my dear and only daughter: what says the note she left, let me again with staider grief peruse it ‚Äî father? wonder not at my so sudden departure, without your leave or knowledge, thus under pardon I excuse it, had you had knowledge of it, I know you would have sought to restrain it, and hinder me from what I have long desired, being now happily preferred to a gentleman's service in London; about Holborn, if you please to send, you may hear well of me ‚Äî
sp.l: As false as she is disobedient,
I've made larger inquiry, left no place
(Where gentry keeps) unsought, yet cannot hear,
Which drives me most into a shameful fear:
Woe worth th' infected cause that makes me visit
This man-devouring city ‚Äî where I spent
My unshapen youth, to be my ages curse,
And surfeited away my name and state,
In swinish riots, that now being sober,
I do awake, a beggar, ‚Äî I may hate her.
Whose youth voids wine, his age is cursed with water,
O heavens! I know the price of ill, too well,
What, the confusions are in whom they dwell,
And how soon maids are to their ruins won
One minute, and eternally undone:
So in mine may it: may it not be thus? ‚Äî
Though she be poor, her honours precious,
May be my present form, and her fond fear,
May chase her from me, if her eye should get me,
And therefore as my love and wants advice.
I'll serve until I find her in disguise.
Such is my care to fright her from base evils
I leave calm state to live amongst you, devils.

div.stage: Lethe's mother enters with Quomodo's wife with the letter.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Were these fit words think you to be sent to any citizens wife, to enjoy the daughter, and love the mother too for a need? I would foully scorn that man, that should love me only for a need I tell you: and here the knave writes again, that by the marriage of my daughter, 'a has the better means and opportunity to myself, he lies in his throat like a villain, he has no opportunity of me, for all that, 'tis for his betters to have opportunity of me, and that he shall well know ‚Äî a base proud knave ‚Äî a has forgotten how he came up, and brought two of his country men to give their words to my husband for a suit of green Karsey, 'a has forgotten all this, and how does he appear to me, when his white satin suttes on, but like a maggot crept out of a nutshell, a fair body and a foul neck, those parts that are covered of him, looks indifferent well, because we cannot see 'em else for all his cleansing, pruning and paring, he's not worthy a broker's daughter, and so tell him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I will indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: And as for my child, I hope she'll be ruled in time, though she be foolish yet and not be carried away with a cast of manchets, a bottle of wine, or a custard, and so I pray certify him.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: He do your errant effectually.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Art thou his aunt ‚Äî or his ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Alas ‚Äî I am a poor drudge of his.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Faith and thou wert his mother, he would make thee his drudge I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Marry out upon him, sir reverence of your mistress-ship

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Here's somewhat for thy pains, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: 'Tis more than he gave me since I came to him.

div.stage: Enter Quomodo and his daughter Su.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now, what prating have we hear? whispers, dumbshows? why Tomazin, go too ‚Äî my shop is not altogether so dark as some of my neighbours, where a man may be made cuckold at one end, while he's measuring with his yard at tother.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Only commendations sent from master Lethe your worshipful son in law that should be.

sp.speaker: Q‚óèo.
sp.p: O, and that you like not ‚ñ™ he that can make us rich in custom, strong in friends, happy in suits, bring us into all the rooms a Sundaies, from the leads to the seller, pop us in with venison till we crack again, and send home the rest in an honourable napkin ‚Äî this man you like not forsooth?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: But I like him father.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: My blessing go with thy liking

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: A number of our citizens hold our credit by't to come home drunk, and say we ha' been at court: then how much more credit is't to be drunk there indeed?

sp.speaker: Qno‚óè.
sp.p: Tut, thy mother's a fool ‚Äî pray what's master Rerage whom you plead for so?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Why, first he is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ay, he's often first a gentleman that's last a beggar.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: My father tells you true, what should I do with a gentleman, I know not which way to lie with him.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: 'Tis true too ‚Äî thou knowest beside, we undo gentlemen daily

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: That makes so few of 'em marry with our daughters, unless it be one green foot or other ‚ñ™ next, m. Rerage has land and living, tother but his walk i'th street, and his snatching diet, he's able to entertain you in a fair house of his own, tother in some nook or corner, or place us behind the cloth like a company of puppets: at his house you shall be served curiously, sit down and eat your meat with leisure, there we must be glad to take it standing, and without either salt, cloth, or trencher, and say we are befriended too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O, that gives a citizen a better appetite than his garden.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: So say I father, methinks it does me most good when I take it standing, I know not how all women's minds are:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith I think they are all of thy mind for that thing, how now Falslight?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: I have descried my fellow Shortyard, alias Blastfield, at hand with the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O my sweet Shortyard! ‚Äî daughter, get you up to your virginals: by your leave mistress Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Why I hope I may sit ith' shop, may I not?

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: That you may, and welcome sweet honey-thigh, but not at this season, there's a buck to be struck.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Well, since I'm so expressly forbidden, I'll watch above ith' gallery, but I'll see your knavery.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Be you prepared as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: You ne'er feared me:

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: O that sweet, neat, comely, proper, delicate parcel of land, like a fine gentlewoman ith' waste: not so great as pretty, pretty: the trees in summer whistling, the silver waters by the banks harmoniously gliding, I should have been a scholar, an excellent place for a student: fit for my son that lately commenced at Cambridge, whom now I have placed at inns of court: thus we that seldom get lands honestly, must leave our heirs to inherit our knavery: but whist, one turn about my shop and meet with 'em.

div.stage: Enter master Easy, with Shortyard, alias Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Is this it sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ay, let me see, this is it: sign of three knaves, 'tis it‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: Do you hear sir, what lack you gentlemen? see good kerseys or broad clothes here, I pray come near ‚Äî master Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I thought you would know me anon.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p:
You're exceeding welcome to town sir, your worship must pardon me, 'tis always misty weather in our shops here: we are a nation the sun here shines upon, ‚Äî came
this gentleman with you?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: O salute him fairly, he's a kind gentleman, a very in ward of mine.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Then I cry you mercy sir, you're especially welcome.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I return you thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But how shall I do for you now master Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It is my greatest affliction at this instant, I am not able to furnish you.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: How master Quomodo, pray say not so, sl'ud you undo me then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Upon my religion master Blastfield, bonds lie forfeit in my hands, I expect the receit of a thousand every hour, and cannot yet set eye of a penny.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's strange methinks .

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: 'Tis mine own pity that plots against me master Blastfield, they know I have no conscience to take the for feature, and that makes 'em so bold with my mercy.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I am sorry for this.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Never the less, if I might entreat your delay but the age of three days to express my sorrow now, I would double the sum, and supply you with four or five hundred.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Let me see, ‚Äî three days.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I good sir, and it may be possible.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Do you hear master Blastfield,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You know I've already invited all the gallants to sup with me tonight .

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: That's true i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Twill be my everlasting shame, if I have no money to maintain my bounty.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: I ne'er thought upon that ‚Äî I looked still when that should come from him, we have strictly examined our expenses, it must not be three days' master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: No then I'm afraid 'twill be my grief sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Master Blastfield, I'll tell you what you may do now.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What good sweet bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Send to master Goome, or master profit, the mercer and goldsmith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Mass that was well remembered of thee ‚Äî I perceive the trout will be a little troublesome ere he be caught ‚Äî boy. „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ boy ‚ñ™ here sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Run to master Goome, or master profit, and carry my present occasion of money to 'em.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I run sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: methinks master Blastfield, you might easily attain to the satisfaction of 3. days, here's a gentleman your friend I dare say will see you sufficiently possessed till then.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Not I sir, by no means: master Blastfield knows I'm further in want then himself, my hope rests all upon him, it stands upon the loss of my credit tonight , if I walk without money.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why master Quomodo, what a fruitless motion have you put forth, you might well assure yourself this gentleman had it not if I wanted it: why our purses are brothers we desire but equal fortunes: in a word we're man and wife, they can but lie together, and so do we.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: As near as can be i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to say truth, 'tis more for the continuing of this gentleman's credit in town than any incitement from mine own want only, that I covet to be so immediately furnished ‚Äî you shall hear him confess as much himself.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Tis most certain master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O here comes the boy now: how now boy, what says master Goome, or master profit?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, they're both walk forth this frosty morning to Brainford, to see a nurse-child.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A bastard be it, spite and shame.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay, never vex yourself sweet master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Bewitched I think.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Do you hear sir? you can persuade with him.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: A little sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
Rather than he should be altogether destitute, or be
too much a vexation to himself, he shall take up a commodity of cloth of me tell him.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why la! by my troth to was kindly spoken.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Two hundred pounds worth upon my religion say.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So disastrously.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay, master Blastfield, you do not hear what master Quomodo said since, like an honest true citizen i'faith: rather than you should grow diseased upon't, you shall take up a commodity of two hundred pounds worth of cloth.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The mealy moth consume it, would he hame turn pedlar now? what should I do with cloth?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He's a very wilful gentleman at this time i'faith: he knows as well what to do with it, as I myself iwis: there's no merchant in town but will be greedy upon't, and pay down money upo'the nail, they'll dispatch it over to Middleborough presently, and raise double commodity by exchange, if not, you know 'tis termtime, and Michaelmas term too, the draper's harvest, for footcloaths, riding suits, walking suits, chamber gowns, and hall gowns.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay, I'll say that, it comes in as fit a time as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take me with you again ere you go sir, I offer him no trash tell him, but present money, say, where I know some gentlemen in town ha' been glad, and are glad at this time, to take up commodities in hawks hoods, and brown paper.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: O horrible, are there such fools in town?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I offer him no trash tell him, upon my religion you may say, ‚Äî now my sweet Shortyard, ‚Äî now the hungry fish begins to nibble: one end of the worm is in his mouth i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why stand I here (As late our graceless dames
That found no eyes) to see that gentleman
Alive in state and credit executed
Help to rip up himself does all he can,
Why am I wife to him that is no man?
I suffer in that gentleman's confusion.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay be persuaded in that master Blastfield 'tis ready money at, the merchants beside, the winterseason and all falls in as pa‚óè as can be to help it.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well master Easie, none but you could have persuaded me to that, come, would you would dispatch then master Quomodo, where's this cloth?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Full and whole within, all of this piece of my religion master Blastfield, feel't, nay feel't and spare not, gentlemen! your fingers and your judgement.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Clothe's good.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: By my troth exceeding good cloth, a good wale t'as,

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: I'm near out a'th' shop sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Go, call in a porter presently to carry away the cloth with the star mark, whither will you please to have it carried master Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Faith to master Beggar-land, he's the only merchant now: or his brother master Stilliard-downe, there's little difference.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You've happened upon the money men sir, they and some of their brethren I can tell you, will not stick to offer thirty thousand pound to be cursed still, great moneyed men, their stocks lie in the poors throats: but you'll see me sufficiently discharged master Blastfield ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: You have always found me righteous in that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You may bring a scrivener along with you.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: I'll remember that sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Have you sent for a citizen master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: No faith not yet ‚Äî boy!

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What must you do with a citizen sir?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: A custom they're bound to o'late by the default of still debtors, no citizen must lend money without two be bound in the bond, the second man enters but for custom's sake.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No, and must he needs be a citizen?

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Byth' mass stay, I'll learn that master Quomodo!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p:
Must the second party that enters into bond only for fashion's sake needs be a citizen? what say you to this gentleman
for one?

sp.speaker: Quomo.
sp.p: A lass sir, you know he's a mere stranger to me, I neither am sure of his going or abiding, he may inn here tonight , and ride away tomorrow, (Although I grant the chief burden lies upon you) yet we are bound to make choice of those we know sir.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Why he's a gentleman of a pretty living sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: It may be so: yet under both your pardons I'd rather have a citizen.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I hope you will not disparage me so? 'tis well known I have three hundred pound a year in Essex,

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Well said, to him thyself, take him up roundly.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: And how doubtfully soe'er you account of me, I do not think but I might make my bond pass for a hundred pound ith' city.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What alone sir?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Alone sir: who says so? perhaps I'd send down for a tenant or too.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ay, that's another case sir.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Another case let it be then.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay, grow not into anger sir.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Not take me into a bond, as good as you shall good man Goosecap.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Well master Blastfield, because I will not disgrace the gentleman, I'm content for once, but we must not make a practice on't.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No sir, now you would you shall not.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Cuds me, I'm undone, he's gone again.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The nets broke.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hold there dear gentleman.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Deny me that small courtesy? 'sfoot a very Jew will not deny it me.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Now must I catch him warily.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: A jest indeed, not take me into a bond quo they.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Master Easie ‚Äî mark my words, if it stood not upon the eternal loss of thy credit against supper ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Mass that's true.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: The pawning of thy horse for his own victuals.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Right i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And thy utter dissolution amongst gentlemen for e‚óè‚óèer.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Pox on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Quomodo should hang, rot, stink.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweet boy i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Drop dam.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I forgotten all this: what meant I to swagger before I had money in my purse? how does master Quomodo? is the bond ready?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Come we must be friends, here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Give it the scrivener: here he comes.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Good day master Quomodo, good morrow gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: We must require a little aid from your pen, good master Dustbox.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: What be the gentlemen's names that are bound sir?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master John Blastfield esquire ith' wild of Kent, and what do they call your bed fellow's name?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Master Richard Easie: you may easily hit on't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master Richard easy of Essex gentleman, both bound to Ephestian Quomodo citizen and draper of London: the sum two hundred pound. What time do you take master Blastfield for the payment?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I never pass my month you know.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I know it sir. October sixteenth today, sixteenth of November say.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Is it your custom to return so soon sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I never miss you.

div.stage: Enter Falslight like a porter, sweating.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I am come for the rest of the same price master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Star-mark, this is it, are all the rest gone?

sp.speaker: Fa‚óè.
sp.p: They're all at master Stilyard downs by this time.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: How the poor rascal's all in a froth?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Push, their ordained to sweat for gentlemen, ‚Äî porters backs and women's bellies bear up the world.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Tis true i'faith, they bear men and money, and that's the world.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You've found it sir.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: I'm ready to your hands gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: It shall be yours I say.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay pray master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I will not i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I should show little bringing up, to take the way of a stranger.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: By my troth you do yourself wrong though master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Not a whit sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: But to avoid strife, you shall have your will of me for once.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let it be so I pray.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Now I begin to set one foot upon the land, methinks I am felling of trees already, we shall have some Essex logs yet to keep Christmas with, and that's a comfort.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.l: Now is he quarting out the executioner.
Strides over him: with his own blood he writes:
I am no dame that can endure such sights.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: So his right wing is cut, will not fly far
Passed the two city hazards, poultry, and Woodstreet.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: How like you my Roman hand i'faith?

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Exceeding well sir, but that you rest too much upon your R. and make your ease too little.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'll mend that presently.

sp.speaker: Dust.
sp.p: Nay 'tis done now, passed mending: you both deliver this to master Quomodo as your deed?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We do sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I thank you gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Would the coin would come away now, we have deserved for't

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: By your leave a little gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what's the matter? speak?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: As fast as I can sir ‚Äî all the clothes come back again .

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What's the news?

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: The passage to middle borrow is stopped, and therefore neither master Stilliard-downe , nor master Beggerland, nor any other merchant will deliver present money upon't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why what hard luck have you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why master Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Pish ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You're so discontented too presently, a man cannot tell how to speak to you?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why what would you say?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: We must make some what on't now sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I where? how? the best is it lies all upon my neck, master Quomodo, can you help me to any money fort? speak

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Troth master Blastfield, since myself is so unfurnished, I know not the means how, there's one ith' street a new setter up, if any lay out money upon't 'twill be he.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: His name:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master idem ‚Äî but you know we cannot give but greatly to your loss, because we gain and live by't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: 'Sfoot will he give any thing.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Ay, stand upon that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Will he give any thing? ‚Äî the brokers will give nothing? to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Falslight.

sp.speaker: Falsl.
sp.p: Over your head sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Desire master idem to come presently and look upo'the cloth.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What if he should offer but a hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: If he want twenty on't let's take it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Master Quomodo we will have four or five hundred pound for you of his own within three or four days.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he said so indeed.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Is that your wife master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: That's she, little Tomazin?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Under your leave sir, I'll show myself a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Do, and welcome master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I have commission for what I do lady from your husband.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You may have a stronger commission for the next, an't please you, that's from myself.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You teach me the best law lady.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Beshrew my blood, a proper, springful, and a sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: My son: Sim Quomodo? here's more work for you master Easie, you must salute him too, for he's like to be heir of thy land I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Vim, vitam, sprinque salutem.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He shows you there he was a Cambridge man sir, but now he's a templar, has he not good grace to make a lawyer?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: A very good grace to make a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: For indeed he has no grace at all.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Some gave me counsel to make him a divine.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But some of our livery think it an unfit thing, that our own sons should tell us of our vices: others, to make him a physician, but then being my heir, I'm afraid he would make me away: now a lawyer they're all willing too, because 'tis good for our trade and increaseth, the number of cloath-gownes, and indeed 'tis the fittest for a citizen's son, for our word is, what do ye lack? and their word is what do you give.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Exceeding proper.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Master idem welcome.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I have seen the cloth sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I am but a young setter up, the uttermost I dare venture upon 'tis threescore pound.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: If it be for me, so, I am for it: if not, you have your doth and I have my money.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay, pray master Blastfield refuse not his kind offer.

sp.speaker: Shs.
sp.p: A bargain than master idem, clap hands ‚Äî he's finely cheated: come, let's all to the next tavern and see the money paid.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I follow you gentlemen, take my son along with you.

Now to my keys: ‚óè‚óème master idem, he must fetch the money, first have I caught him in a bond for two hundred pound, and my two hundred pounds worth a doath again for threescore pound: admire me all you students at inns for cozenage.

div.head: Incipit actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter Lethe's pander, Helgill, the countries wench coming in with a new fashion gawne dressed gentlewoman like, the tailor pointes it, and a tire-woman busy about her head.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: You talk of an alteration, here's the thing itself, what base birth does not raiment make glorious? and what glorious births do not ?agges make infamous? why should not a woman confess what she is now? since the finest are but deluding shadows, begotten between tire-women and tailors? for instance, behold their parents.

sp.speaker: Comings
sp.p: Say what you will, this wire becomes you best, how say you tailor?

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: I promise you 'tis a wire would draw me from my work seven days a week.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why do you work a Sundaies tailor?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Hardest of all a Sunday, because we are most forbidden

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Troth and so do most of us women, the better day the better deed we think.

sp.speaker: Comings
sp.p: Excellent exceeding i'faith, a narrow card wire sets out a cheek so fat and so full, and if you be ruled by me, you shall wear your hair still like a mock-face behind, 'tis such an Italian world, many men know not before from behind.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.p: How like you the fitting of this gown now mistress Comings?

sp.speaker: Comings
sp.p: It sits at marvellous good ease, and comely discretion.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Who would think now this fine sophisticated squall came out of the bosom of a barn, and the loins of a haytosser.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Out you saucy pestiferous pander, I scorn that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Excellent, already the true phrase and style of a strumpet, stay, a little more of the red, and then I take my leave of your cheek for four and twenty hours ‚Äî do you not think it impossible that her own father should know her now, if he saw her?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why I think no less, how can he know me, when I scarce know myself.

sp.speaker: Helg:
sp.p: 'Tis right.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: But so well you lay wait for a man for me.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: I protest I have bestowed much labour about it, and in fit time, good news I hope.

div.stage: Enter one bringing in her father in disguise to serve her.
div.p: 1 I've found one yet at last, in whose preferment I hope to reap credit.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is that the fellow?
1 lady it is.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Art thou willing to serve me fellow?

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: So please you, he that has not the heart to serve such a mistress as your beautiful self, deserves to be honoured for a fool, or knighted for a coward.

sp.speaker: Curtiz.
sp.p: There's to many of them already.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: 'Twere sin then to raise the number.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Well, we'll try both our likings for a month, and then either proceed, or let fall the suit.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Be it as you have spoke, but 'tis my hope a longer term.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No truly, our term ends once a month, we should get more than the lawyers, for they have but four terms a year, and we have twelve, and that makes 'em run so fast to us in the vacation.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: A mistress of of a choice beauty, amongst such imperfect creatures I ha' not seen a perfecter: I should have reckoned the fortunes of my daughter amongst the happiest, had she lighted into such a service, whereas now I rest doubt full, whom or where she serves.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: There's for your bodily advice tailor, and there's for your head-counsel, and I discharge you both till to morrow morning again.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: At which time our neatest attendance.

sp.speaker: Coin.
sp.p: I pray have an especial care howsoever you stand or lie, that nothing fall upon your hair to batter your wire.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I warrant you for that ‚Äî which gown becomes me best now, the purple satin or this?

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: If my opinion might rule over you ‚Äî

div.stage: Enter Lethe with Rerage and Salewood.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Come gallants, I'll bring you to a beauty shall strike your eyes into your hearts, what you see you shall desire, yet never enjoy.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And that's a villainous torment.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: And is she but your underput master Lethe?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No more of my credit, and a gentlewoman of a great house, noble parentage, unmatchable education, my plain Pung. I may, grace her with the name of a courtesan, a backslider, a prostitution, or such a toy, but when all comes to all 'tis but a plain Pung, look you gentlemen, that's she, behold her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: O my beloved strayer! I consume in thy absence.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: La you now ‚Äî you shall not say I'll be proud to you gentlemen, I give you leave to salute her ‚ñ™ I me afraid of nothing now, but that she'll utterly disgrace 'em, turn tail to 'em, and place their kisses behind her, no by my faith, she deceives me, by my troth sha's kissed am both with her lips: I thank you for that music masters, 'slid they both court her at once, and see if she ha' not the wit to stand still and let 'em: I think if two men were brewed into one, there is that woman would drink 'em up both.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: A coxcomb, he a courtier.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He says he has a place there.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: So has the fool a better place than he, and can come where he dare not show his head.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Nay, he are you me gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I protest you were the last man we spoke on, we're a little busy yet, pray stay there a while, we'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: This is good i'faith, endure this and be a slave forever, since you neither savour of good breeding nor bringing up, I'll slice your hamstrings but I'll make you show mannerly ‚Äî pox on you, leave courting, I ha' not the heart to hurt an Englishman i'faith, or else ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Prithee let's be merry, nothing else ‚Äî here, fetch some wine.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let my servant go for't.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Yours, which is he?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This sir, but I scarce like my mistress now: the loins can ne'er be safe where the flies be so busy ‚Äî wit by experience bought foils wit at school: who proves a deeper knave than a spent fool, I am gone for your worship's wine sir.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: Sir, you put up too much indignity, bring company to cut your own throat, the fire is not yet so hot, that you need two screens before it, 'tis but new kindled yet, if 'twere risse to a flame, I could not blame you them to put others before you but alas all the heat yet is comfortable a cherisher, not a defacer.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prithee let 'em alone, they'll be ashamed o't anon I trow, if they have any grace in 'em.

sp.speaker: Helg.
sp.p: I'd fain have him quarrel, fight, and be assuredly killed, that I might beg his place: for there's ne'er a one void yet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: You'll make him mad anon.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: 'Tis to that end.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Yet at last, master Quomodo is as firm as his promise.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Did I not tell you still he would.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Let me see, I am seven hundred pound in bond now to the rascal.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay you're no less master Blastfield, look to't, by my troth, I must needs confess sir, you ha' been uncommonly kind to me, since I ha' been in town, but master Alsup shall know on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's my ambition sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I beseech you sir. Stay, this is Lethe's haunt, see, we have caught him.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Master Blastfield and master Easie, you're kind gentlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is that the beauty you famed so?

sp.speaker: Leeh.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Who be those so industrious about her?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Rerage and Salewood: I'll tell you the unmannerlyest trick of 'em, that ever you heard in your life.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Prithee what's that?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I invited 'em hither to look upon her, brought 'em along with me, gave 'em leave to salute her in kindness, what do they but most saucily fall in love with her, very impudently court her for themselves, and like two crafty attorneys, finding a hole in my lease, go about to defeat me of my right.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ha they so little conscience?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The most uncivil'st part that you have seen, I know they'll be sorry for't when they have done, for there's no man but gives a sigh after his sin of women, I know it by myself.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You parcel of a rude, saucy and unmannerly nation.

sp.speaker: Lethe.
sp.p: One good thing in him, he'll tell 'em on't roundly.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Cannot a gentleman purchase a little fire to thaw his appetite by, but must you that have been daily singed in the flame, be as greedy to beguile him on't? how can it appear in you but maliciously, and that you go about to engross hell to yourselves? he aven forbid, that you should not suffer a stranger to come in, the devil himself is not so unmannerly, I do not think but some of them rather will be wise enough to beg ‚ñ™ offices there before you, and keep you out, marry all the spite will be they cannot sell 'em again.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Come, are you not to blame ‚Äî not to give place? ‚Äî to us I mean ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A worse and a worse disgrace.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen, you wrong us both then, stand from me, I protest I'll draw my silver bodkin upon you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Clubs, clubs, ‚Äî gentlemen stand upon your guard.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: A gentlewoman must swagger a little now and then I perceive, there would be no civility in her chamber else, though it be my hard fortune to have my keeper there a coward, the thing that's kept is a gentlewoman born.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And to conclude a coward, infallible of your side, why do you think i'faith I took you to be a coward? do I think you'll turn your back to any man living? you'll be whipped first.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: And then indeed she turns her back to some man living.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But that man shows himself a knave, for he dares not show his own face when he does it, for some of the common counsel in Henry the eights days thought it modesty at that time, that one vizard should look upon another.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: 'Twas honestly considered of 'em i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? what piece of stuff comes here?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Now some good news yet to recover my repute, and grace me in this company; gentlemen, are we friends among ourselves?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Vinited.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Then here comes Revish to confirm our amity ‚Äî wag ‚ñ™ tail, salute them all they are friends.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Then saving my quarrel to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Toe's all

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Now be shrew your hearts, and you do not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To sweet master Lethe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let it flow this way dear master Blastfield, gentlemen to you all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This Rhenish wine is like the scouring-stick to a gun, it makes the barrel clear: it has an excellent virtue, it keeps all the sinks in man and woman's body sweet in June and July, and to say truth, if ditches were not cast once a year, and drabs once a month, there would be no abiding i'th city.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'll make you privy to a letter I sent.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A letter comes well after privy, it makes amends.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: There's one Quomodo ‚ñ™ a draper's daughter in town whom for her happy portion I wealthily affect.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And not for love? this makes for me his rival, bear witness.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: The father does elect me for the man, the daughter says the same.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: Yes all but for the mother, she's my sickness.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: By‚Äôr lady and the mother is a pestilent, wilful, troublesome sickness I can tell you, if she light upon you handsomely.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I find it so: she for a stranger pleads: whose name I ha' not learned.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And e'en now he called me by it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now as my letter told her, since only her consent kept aloof of, what might I think on't, but that she merely doted upon me herself.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Very assuredly.

sp.speaker: Salt.
sp.p: This makes still for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Did you let it go so i'faith?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You may believe it sir, now what says her answer?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ay, her answer.

sp.speaker: Gruil.
sp.p: She says you're a base proud knave, and like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Nay, hear out her answer, or there's no goodness in you.

sp.speaker: Grui.
sp.p: You ha' forgotten she says in what pickle your worship came up, and brought two of your friends to give their words for a suit of green kersey.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Drudge, peace, or ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Show yourself a gentleman, she had the patience to read your letter which was as bad as this can be, what will she think on't, not hear her answer? speak, good his drudge.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p: And as for her daughter, she hopes she'll be ruled by her in time, and not be carried away with a cast of manchets, a bottle of wine, and a custard, which once made her daughter sick, because you came by it with a bad conscience.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm all in a sweat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's very wholesome for your body, nay you must keep in your arms.

sp.speaker: Gru.
sp.p: Then she demanded of me whether I was your worship's aunt or no?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Out, out, out, Gru. alas said I, I am a poor drudge of his.

div.p: Faith and thou wert his mother (Quoth she) heed make thee his drudge I warrant him ‚Äî
Marry out upon him (Quoth I) an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Horror, horror, I'm smothered, let me go, torment me not.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you love me, let's follow him gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I count a hundred pound well spent to pursue a good jest master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: By my troth I begin to bear that mind too.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Well said i'faith, hang money-good jests are worth silver at all times.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: They're worth gold master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Do you deceive me so? are you towards marriage i'faith master Lethe it shall go hard but I'll forbid the banes, I'll send a messenger into your bones, another into your purse but I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Thou fair and wicked creature, steeped in art,
Beauteous and fresh, the soul the foulest part.
A common filth, is like a house possessed,
Where if not spoilt, you'll come out frayed at least,
This service likes not me, though I rest poor,
I hate the basest use to screen a whore.
The human stroke ne'er made him, he that can
Be bawd to woman, never leapt from man.
Some monster won his mother,
I wished my poor child hither, doubled wrong,
A month and such, a mistress were too long,
Yet here a while in others lives I'll see,
How former follies, did appear in me.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Where left you master Blastfield your master, say you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: An hour since I left him in Paul's sir ‚Äî but you'll not find him the same man again next time you meet him.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Methinks I have no being without his company 'tis so full of kindness and delight, I hold him to be the only companion in earth.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ay, as companions go now adays that help to spend a man's money.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: So full of nimble wit, various discourse, pregnant apprehension, and uncommon entertainment, he might keep company with any lord for his grace.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ay, with any lord that were passed it.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p:
And such a good free hearted honest, affable kind of
gentleman: come boy a heaviness will possess me till I see him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But you'll find yourself heavier then, by a seven hundred pound weight, ‚Äî alas poor birds that cannot keep the sweet country, where they sly at pleasure, but must needs come to London to have their wings clipped, and are fain to go hopping home again.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falslight like a sarieant and a yeoman to arrest easy.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So, no man is so impudent to deny that ‚Äî spirits can change their shapes, and soonest of all into sergeants: because they are cousin germane to spirits, for there's but two kind of arrests till doomsday, the devil for the soul, the sergeant for the body, but afterwards the devil arrests body and soul sergeant and all, if they be knaves still, and deserve it ‚ñ™ now my yeoman Falslight.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I attend you good sergeant Shortyard.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: No more master Blastfield now ‚Äî poor Easie hardly be set.

sp.speaker: Fals‚óè.
sp.p: But how if he should go to prison, were in a mad state then, being not sergeants.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Never let it come near thy belief that he'll take prison, or stand out in law, knowing the debt to be due, but still expect the presence of master Blastfield, kind m. Blastfield, worshipful m Blastfield ‚Äî and at the last ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master Shortyard, master Falslight.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The boy: a warning-piece, ‚Äî see where he comes.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Is not in Paul's.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is not far off sure sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: When was his hour sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Two sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why two has struck.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No sir, they are now a striking.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Master Richard easy of Essex we arrest you.
