sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alas a surgeon, he's hurt ith' shoulder.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Deliver your weapons quietly sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You're arrested at the suit of m. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How strange you make it, you're a landed gentleman sir, I knew 'tis but a trifle, a bond of seven hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: La, I know you had mistook, you should arrest one master Blastfield, 'tis his bond, his debt.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Is not your name there?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: True, for fashion's sake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why and 'tis for fashion's sake that we arrest you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nay, and it be no more, I yield to that: I know master Blastfield will see me take no injury as long as I'm in town, for master Alsup's sake.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Who's that sir?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: An honest gentleman in Essex.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O, in Essex! I thought you had been in London, where now your business lies, honesty from Essex will be a great while a coming sir, you should look out an honest pair of citizens.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Alas sir, I know not where to find 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: No, there's enough in town.

sp.speaker: Eas‚óè.
sp.p: I know not one by my troth, I am a mere stranger for these parts, master Quomodo is all, and the honestest that I know.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: To him then let's set forward: ‚Äî yeoman Spiderman, cast an eye about for master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Boy ‚Äî alas the poor boy was frighted away at first.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Can you blame him sir ‚Äî we that daily fray away knights, may fright away boys I hope.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ha? have they him sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As sure as ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: The land's mine, that's sure enough boy.
Let me advance thee knave, and give thee a kiss,
My plot's so firm I dare it now to miss.
Now shall I be divulged a landed man,
Throughout the livery: ‚Äî one points, another whispers,
A third frets inwardly: let him fret and hang,
Especially his envy I shall have,
That would be fain, yet cannot be a knave,
Like an old leather girt in furred gown,
Whose mind stands stiff but his performance down.
Now come my golden days in: ‚Äî whither is the worshipful
Master Quomodo, and his fair bedfellow rid forth,
To his land in Essex? whence comes those goodly load of
Logs? from his land in Essex? where grows this pleasant
Fruit, says one citizen's wife in the row; at master Quomodo's
Orchard in Essex; o, o, does it so, I thank you for
That good news i'faith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here they come with him sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Grant me patience in my joys, that being so great I run not mad with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Bless master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How now sergeants? who ha' you brought me here, master Easie?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why la you now sergeants, did I not tell you you mistook?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Did you not hear me say. I had rather ha' had master Blastfield, the more sufficient man a great deal?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Very true sir, ‚Äî but this gentleman lighting into our hands first ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why did you so sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We thought good to make use of that opportunity, and hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You did well in that I must needs say, for your own securities, but 'twas not my mind master Easie to have you first, you must needs think so.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I dare swear that master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: But since you are come to me, I have no reason to refuse you, I should show little manners in that sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p:
But I hope you spoke not in that sense sir, to impose
the bond upon me.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: By my troth that's my meaning sir, you shall find me an honest man, you see I mean what I say, is not the day past, the money untendered, you'd ha' me live uprightly master Easie?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why sir, you know master Blastfield is the man.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why sir, I know master Blastfield is the man, but is he any more than one man? two entered into bond to me, or I'm foully cozened.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You know my entrance was but for fashion's sake.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why, I'll a 'gree to you, you'll grant 'tis the fashion likewise when the bond's due to have the money paid again.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: So we told him sir, and that it lay in your worship's courtesy to arrest which you please.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Marry does it sir, these fellows know the law, ‚Äî beside, you offered yourself into bond to me you know, when I had no stomach to you, now beshrew your heart for your labour, I might ha' had a good substantial citizen, that would ha' paid the sum roundly, although I think you sufficient enough for seven hundred pound, beside the forfeiture, I would be loath to disgrace you so much before sergeants.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: If you would hath patience sir, I do not think but master Blasefield is at carriers to receive the money.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He will prove the honester man then, and you the better discharged, I wonder he should break with me, was never his practice, you must not be angry with me now, though you were somewhat hot when you entered into bond, you may easily go in angrily, but you cannot come out so.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No, the devils in't for that.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Do you here sir, a my troth we pity you, ha' you any store of crowns about you?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Faith a poor store, yet they shall be at their service that will strive to do me good, ‚Äî we were both drunk last night, and ne'er thought upon the bond.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I must tell you this, you have fallen in to the hands of a most merciless devourer, the very gull a'th' city, should you offer him money, goods or lands now, he'd rather have your body in prison, he's a such a nature. Eas. prison we're undone then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: He's a such a nature, look? ‚Äî let him owe any man a spite‚óè what's his course: he will lend him money today, a purpose to rest him tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Defend me?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Has at least sixteen at this instant proceeded in both the counters: some bachelor, some masters, some doctors of captivity of 20. years standing and he desires nothing more than imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Would ma. Blastfield would come away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Ay, than things would not be as they are ‚Äî what will you say to us if we procure you two substantial subsidy citizens to bail you spite on's heart, and set you at liberty to find out master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Serjeant! here, take all, I'll be dear to you, do but perform it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Much.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: Enough sweet sergeant, I hope I understand thee.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I love to prevent the malice of such a rascal, perhaps you might find master Blastfield tonight .

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why, we lie together man, there's the jest on't.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Fie. ‚Äî and you'll seek to secure your bail, because they will be two citizens of good account, you must do that for your credit's sake.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'll be bound to save them harmless.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A pox on him, you cut his throat then, ‚Äî no words.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What's it you require me master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You know that before this time I hope sir, present money, or present imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I told you so.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: We ne'er had money of you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You had commodities, an't please you

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Well, may I not crave so much liberty upon my word, to seek out master Blastfield?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Yes, and you would not laugh at me: we are sometimes gulls to gentlemen ‚ñ™ I thank 'em; but gentlemen are never gulls to us, I commend 'em.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Under your leave master Quomodo, the gentleman craves the furtherance of an hour, and it sorts well with our
occasion at this time, having a little urgent business at Guildhall, at which minute we'll return, and see what agreement is made.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Nay take him along with you sergeant.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'm undone then.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: He's your prisoner; and being safe in your house at your own disposing, you cannot deny him such a request: beside, he hath a little faith in ma. Blastfield's coming sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Let me not be too long delayed I charge you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Not an hour i'faith sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O master Easie, of all men living I never dream ‚ñ™ you would ha' done me this injury: make me would my credit, fail in my commodities, ring my state into suspicion: for the breaking of your day to me, has broken my day to others.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You tell me of that still, which is no fault of mine master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O what's a man but his honesty master Easie, and that's a fault amongst most of us all, ‚Äî mark but this note, I'll give you good counsel now, ‚Äî as often as you give your name to a bond, you must think you christen a child, and take the charge on't too: for as the one, the bigger it grows the more cost it requires: so the other the longer it lies, the more charges it puts you too, only here's the difference a child must be broke, and a bond must not, the more you break children, the more you keep 'em under: but the more you break bonds, the more they'll leap in your face, and therefore, to conclude, I would never undertake to be gossip to that bond which I would not see well brought up.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Say you so sir? ‚Äî I'll think upon your counsel hereafter for't.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ah fool, thou shouldst ne'er ha' tasted such wit but that I know 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The more I grieve:

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: To put all this into the compass of a little hoop ring
Make this account, come better days or worse,
So many bonds abroad, so many boys at nurse.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p:
A good medicine for a short memory: ‚Äî but since,
you have entered so far, whose children are desperate depts I pray?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Faith they are like the offsprings of stolen lust, put to the hospital, their fathers are not to be found, they are either too far abroad, or too close within, and thus for your memory's sake.
sp.l: The desperate debtor hence derives his name,
One that has neither money, land nor fame,
All that he makes, prove bastards, and not bonds,
But such as yours, at first are horn‚óè to lands.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: But all that I beget hereafter I'll so one disinherit master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: In the mean time here's a shrewd knave will disinherit you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Well, to put you out of all doubt master Quomodo, I'll not trust to your courtesy, I ha' sent for bail.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How? you've cozened me there i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Since the worst comes to the worst, I have those friends ith' city, I hope that will not suffer me to lie for seven hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: And you told me you had no friends here at all, how should a man trust you now?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: That was but to try your courtesy m. Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How unconscionably he gulls himself ‚Äî they must be wealthy subsidie-men sir, at least forty pound ith' Kings books I can tell you, that do such a feat for you.

div.stage: Enter Shortyard and Falslight, like wealthy citizens in satin suits.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Here they come whatsoe'er they are.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: By‚Äôr lady alderman's deputies, I am very sorry for you sir, I cannot refuse such men.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Are you the gentleman in distress?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: None more than myself sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He speaks truer than he thinks, for if he knew, the hearts that owe those faces ‚Äî a dark shop's good for somewhat.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: That was all sir.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: And that's enough, for by that means you have made yourself ‚óèable to the bond, as well as that Basefield

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Blastfield sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O cry you mercy 'tis Blastfield indeed.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: But under both your worship's favours I know where to find him presently.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: That's all your refuge.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: News, good news master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master Blastfield my master has received a thousand pound, and will be at his lodging at supper.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Happy‚óè news, hear you that master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: 'Tis enough for you to hear that, you're the fortunate man sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Not now I beseech your good worships.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentleman, what's your other name?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Easy.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: O master Easie ‚Äî I would we could rather pleasure you otherwise master Easie, you should soon perceive it, I'll speak a proud word we have pitied more gentlemen in distress, than any two citizens within the freedom ‚Äî but to be bail to seven hundred pound action, is a matter of shroud weight.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'll be bound to secure you.

sp.speaker: Shor.
sp.p: Tut, what's your bond sir?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Body, goods, and lands, immediately before master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Shall we venture once again, that have been so often undone by gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I have no great stomach to't, it will appear in us more pity than wisdom.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Why should you say so sir?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I like the gentleman's face well, he does not look as if he would deceive us.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: O not I sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p:
Come we'll make a desperate voyage once again,
we'll try his honesty, and take his single bond, of body goods and lands.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I dear thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Master Quomodo?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worships.

sp.speaker: Shortyard.
sp.p: We have taken a course to set your prisoner free.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your worships are good bail you content me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Come then, and be a witness to a recullisance.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: With all my heart sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Master Easie, you must have an especial care now to find out that Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I shall have him at my lodging sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The suit will „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ you selse, master Quomodo will come upon ut, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I know that sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Well since I see you have such a good mind to be honest ‚óèe leave some greater „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ sweat with you to find him myself.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Heare then my misery ends „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a stranger's kindness oft exceeds a friend's.

sp.speaker: „Äà‚óä„Äâ.
sp.l: Thou art deceived thy misery but begins,
"To beguile goodness, is the core of sins.
My love is such unto thee, that I die
As often as thou drinkest up „Äà‚óä„Äâ ‚ñ™
Yet have no means to warn thee from't, for he
" that sows in craft, does rape in jealousy.

sp.speaker: Rerrage.
sp.p: Now the letters made up and all, it wants but the print of a seal, and away it goes to master Quomodo: Andrew Le‚óèhe is well whipped in't, his name stands in a white sheet here, and do penance for him.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: You have shame enough against him, if that be good.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: First as a contempt of that reverend ceremony, he has in hand, to wit, marriage.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Why do you say to wit marriage, when you know there's none will marry that's wise.

sp.speaker: R‚óèr.
sp.p: Had it not more need then, to have wit to put to't if it be grown to a ‚óèolly?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: You've ‚óèun, I'll give't you.

sp.speaker: Rerag.
sp.p: 'Tis no thanks now, ‚Äî but as I was saying: as a soul contempt to that sacred ceremony, he most audaciously keeps a drab in town, and to be free from the interruption of blue beadles, and other bawdy officers, he most politicly lodges her in a constable's house.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: That's a pretty point i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: And so the watch that should fetch her out ‚ñ™ are her chiefest guard to keepe her in.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: It must needs be for look how the constable plays his conscience, the watchmen will follow the suit.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why well then.

div.stage: Enter Easy with Shortyard like a citizen.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: All night from me he's hurt, he's made away.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Where shall we seek him now? you lead me fair daunt's sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Pray keep a little patience sir, I shall find him at last you shall see.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A citizen of my ease and substance to walk so long a foot.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You should ha' had my horse but that he has eaten out his head sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How would you had me hold him by the tail sir then?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Manners forbid, 'tis no part of my meaning sir, ‚Äî o here's master Rerage, and master Salewood, now we shall hear of him presently: ‚Äî gentlemen both.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: Master Easie, how fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Very well in health, did you see master Blastfield this morning?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I was about to move it to you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: We were all three in a mind then.

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p: I ha' not set eye on him these two days.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wonder he keeps so long from us i'faith.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I began to be sick.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Nothing in troth, but a great desire I had to have seen him.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: I wonder you should miss on't lately, you're his bedfellow

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I lay alone tonight i'faith, ‚Äî I do not know how, oh here comes master Lethe, he can dispatch me: master Lethe!

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: What's your name sir? ‚Äî oh cry you mercy master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: When parted you from master Blastfield sir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Blastfield's an ass, I have sought him these two days to beat him.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Yourself all alone sir?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Ay, and three more. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I am glad, I am where I am then, I perceive 'twas time of all hands.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Content i'faith, let's trace him.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: What? have you found him yet? neither? what's to be done now? I'll venture my body no further for any gentleman's pleasure, I know not how soon I may be called upon, and now to overheat myself. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: This is you that slept with him, you can make fools of us, but I'll turn you over to Quomodo fort.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I'll prevent mine own danger.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Though I love gentlemen well, I do not mean to be undone for 'em.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Pray sir, let me request you sir, sweet sir, I beseech you sir.

div.head: Incipit quartus.
div.stage: Enter Quomodo, his disguised spirits, after whom Easy follows hard.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Made fools of us! not to be found!

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What, what?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Do not undo me quite though ma Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: You're very welcome, master Easie, I ha' nothing to say to you, I'll not touch you, you may go when you please, ‚Äî I have good bail here I thank their worships.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What shall I say, or whom shall I beseech ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Gentlemen, 'slid they were born to undo us I think, but for my part, I'll make an oath before master qomodo here, ne'er to do gentlemen good while I live.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: I'll not be long behind you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Away; if you had any grace in you, you would be ashamed to look us ith' face, iwis I wonder with what brow you can come amongst us, I should seek my fortunes farre enough if I were you, and neither return to Essex, to be a shame to my predecessors, nor remain about London, to be a mock to my successors.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Subtle Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Here are his lands forfeited to us master Quomodo, and to avoid the inconscionable trouble of law, all the assistance he made to us, we willingly resign to you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What shall I do with rubbish, give me money: 'tis for your worships to have land, that keep great houses, I should be hoisted.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: But master Quomodo, if you would but conceive it aright, the land would fall fitter to you then to us.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Curtzing about my land.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: You have a towardly son and heir as we hear.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I must needs say, he is a templar indeed.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: We have neither posterity in town nor hope for any abroad; we have wives, but the marks have been out of their mouths these twenty years, and as it appears, they did little good when they were in: we could not stand about it sir, to get riches and children too ‚ñ™ 'tis more than one man can do. And I am of those citizens' minds that say, let our wives make shift for children and they will, they get none of us; and I cannot think, but he that has both much wealth and many children, has had more helps coming in then himself.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I am not a bow wide of your mind sir. ‚Äî and for the thirsty and covetous hopes I have in my son and heir Sim qmomodo, that he will never trust his land in wax and parchment as many gentlemen have done before him.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: All y-blow for me.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I will honestly discharge you, and receive it in due form and order of law, to strengthen it for ever to my son and heir, that he may undoubtedly enter upon't without the let or molestation of any man, at his or our pleasure whensoever.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: 'Tis so assure unto you.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why then master Basie you're a freeman sir, you may deal in what you please, and go whether you will. Why Tomazin, master Easie is dome from Essex, bid him welcome in a cup of small bear.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Not only vild, but in it tyrannous.

sp.speaker: Quom.
sp.p: If it please you sir, you know the house, you may visit us often ‚ñ™ and dine with us once a quarter.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.l: Confusion light on you, your wealth and heir,
Worm gnaw your conscience, as the moth your ware,
I am not the first heir that robbed, or begged.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Excellent excellent, sweet spirits.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Landed master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Delicate Shortyard, commodious Falslight,
Hug and away, shift, shift.
'Tis slight, not strength that gives the greatest lift.
Now my desires are full ‚Äî for this time,
Men may have cormorant wishes, but alas
A little thing three hundred pound a year,
Suffices nature, keeps life and soul together,
I'll have 'em kept immediately.
sp.p:
I long to warm myself by'th wood, ‚Äî a fine journey in the Whitsun-holy days i'faith, to ride down with a number of citizens, and their wives, some upon pillions, some upon side saddles, ay, and little Tomazin ith' middle our some and heir Sim Quomodo in a peach colour taffeta jacket, some horses length, or a long yard before us, there will be a fine show on's I can tell you, where we citizens will laugh, and lie down get all our wives with child against a bank and get up again, astay, ha hast thou that wit i'faith 'twill ‚ñ™ be admirable, to see how the very thought of green fields puts a man into sweet inventions. I will presently possess Sim
Quomodo of all the land, I have a toy and I'll do't: and because I see before mine eyes that most of our heirs prove notorious rioters after our deaths, and that cousinage in the father wheels about to folly in the son, our posterity commonly foiled at the same weapon, at which we played rarely. And being the world‚óè beaten word, what's got over the devil's back, (That's by knavery) must be spent under his belly, (That's by lechery) being awake in these knowings, why should not I oppose 'em now, and break destiny of her custom, preventing that by policy, which without it must needs be destiny? and I have taken the course, I will forthwith sicken, call for my keys, make my will, and dispose of all, give my son this blessing, that he trust no man, keep his hand from a quean, and a scrivener, live in his father's faith, and do good to nobody : then will I begin to rave like a fellow of a wide conscience, and for all the world counterfeit to the life, that which I know I shall do when I die, take on for my gold, my lands, and my writings, grow worse and worse, call upon the devil, and so make an end ‚ñ™ by this time I have indented with a couple of searchers, who to uphold my device shall fray them out a'th chamber with report of sickness, and so la, I start up, and recover again: for in this business I will trust, no not my spirits Falslight and Shortyard, but in disguise note the condition of all, how pitiful my wife takes my death, which will appear by November in her eye, and the fall of the leaf in her body, but especially by the cost she bestows upon my funeral, there shall I try her love and regard, my daughters marrying to my will and liking, and my son's affection after my disposing: for to conclude ‚ñ™ I am as jealous of this land as of my wife, to know what would become of it after my decease.

div.stage: Enter courtesan with her disguised father.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: Though I be poor, 'tis my glory to live honest.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I prithee do not leave me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.l: To be bawd.
Hell has not such an office,
I thought at first your mind had been preserved,
In virtue and in modesty of blood,
that such a face had not been made to please the unsettled appetites of several men,
Those eyes turned up through prayer, not through lust,
But you are wicked, and my thoughts unjust.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why thou art an unreasonable fellow i'faith, do not all trades live by their ware, and yet called honest livers? do they not thrive best, when they utter most, and make it away by the great? is not wholesale the chiefest merchandise? do you think some merchants could keep their wives so brave but for their wholesale? you're foully deceived and you think so.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: You are so glued to punishment and shame, your words e'en deserve whipping ‚Äî to bear the habit of a gentlewoman, and be in mind so distant.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Why you fool you, are not gentlewomen sinners? and there's no courageous sinner amongst us, but was a gentlewoman by the mother's side I warrant you: besides, we are not always bound to think those our fathers that marry our mothers, but those that lie with our mothers, and they may be gentlemen born and born again for ought we know, you know.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.p: True: corruption may well be generations first, we're bad by nature, but by custom worst.

div.stage: A bell toales, a confused cry within.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O my husband.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: My father, oh my father.

sp.speaker: Fals.
sp.p: My sweet master, dead!

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: Run boy, bid 'em ring out, he's dead, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then is as arrant a knave gone, as ere was called upon.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: The happiest good that ever Shortyard felt,
I want to be expressed, my mirth is such,
To be struck now e'en when his joys were high,
Men only kiss their knaveries, and so die,
I've often marked it.
He was a famous cozener while he lived,
And now his son shall reap it, I'll ha' the lands,
Let him study law after, 'tis no labour
to undo him for ever: but for Easie,
Only good confidence did make him foolish,
And not the lack of sense, that was not it,
'Tis worldly craft beats down a scholar's wit,
For this our son and heir now, he
From his conception was entailed an ass,
And he has kept it well, twenty five years now,
Than the sleightest art will do't, the lands lie fair,
No sin to beggar a deceiver's heir.

div.stage: Enter Tomazin with Winefride her maid in haste.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Here Winifred, here, here, here, I have always found thee secret.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: You shall always find me so mistress.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Take this letter and this ring.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O how all the parts about me shake, ‚Äî inquire for one master easy at his old lodging ith' the Blackfriars,

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I will indeed forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Tell him the party that sent him a hundred pound tother day to comfort his heart, has likewise sent him this letter and this ring, which has that virtue to recover him again for ever say ‚Äî name nobody Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Not so much as you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Good girl, thou shalt have a mourning gown at the burial of mine honesty.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And I'll effect your will a my fidelity.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I do account myself the happiest widow that ever counterfeited weeping, in that I have the leisure now, both to do that gentleman good, and do myself a pleasure, but I must seem like a hanging moon a little waterish a while.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I entertain both thee and thy device,
'Twill put 'em both to shame.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: That is my hope sir,
Especially that strumpet.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: Save you sweet widow,
I suffer for your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O master Rerage, I have lost the dearest husband that ever woman did enjoy.

sp.speaker: Rerg.
sp.p: You must have patience yet.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O talk not to me of patience and you love me, good master Rerage.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Yet if all tongues go right, he did not use you so well as a man might.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Nay, that's true indeed master Rerage, he ne'er used me so well as a woman might have been used, that's certain in troth t'has been our greatest falling out sir, and though it be the part of a widow, to show herself a woman for her husband's death, yet when I remember all his unkindness, I cannot weep a stroke i'faith master Rerage, and therefore wisely did a great widow in this land, comfort up another, go too lady (Quoth she) leave blubbering, thou thinkest upon thy husbands good parts when thou shedst tears, do but remember how often he has lain from thee, and how many naughty slippery turns he has done thee, and thou wilt ne'er weep for him I warrant thee ‚Äî you would not think how that counsel has wrought with me master Rerage, I could not dispend another tear now, and you would give me never so much.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Why I count you the wiser widow, it shows you have wisdom, when you can check your passion, for mine own part, I have no sense to sorrow for his death, whose life was the only rub to my affection.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Troth and so it was to mine, but take courage now, you're a landed gentleman, and my daughter is seven hundred pound strong to join with you.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: But Lethe lies ith' way.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: Let him lie still, you shall tread o'er him or I'll fail in will.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What a beloved man did I live? my servants gall their fingers with ringing, my wife's cheeks smart with weeping,
stand in every corner, you may take water in my house ‚Äî but am not I a wise fool now? what if my wife should take my death so to heart, that she should sicken upon't, nay swoon, nay die? when did I hear of a woman do so, let me see, ‚Äî now I remember me, I think 'twas before my time; yes, I have heard of those wives that have wept, and sobbed, and swoon ‚Äî marry I never heard but they recovered again, that's a comfort la, that's a comfort, and I hope so will mine ‚Äî peace, 'tis near upon the time, I see, here comes the worshipful livery, I have the hospital boys, I perceive little Tomazin will bestow cost of me, ‚Äî I'll listen to the common censure now, how the world tongues me when my ear lies low.

sp.speaker: 1. Live.
sp.p: Who Quomodo? merely enriched by shifts, and cozenages, believe it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I see the world is very loath to praise me,
'Tis rawly friends with me, I cannot blame it,
For what I have done, has been to vex and shame it.
Here comes my son, the hope, the landed heir,
On't whose rare thrift, will say men's tongues you lie,
I'll keep by law what was got craftily.
Methinks I hear him say so:
He does salute the livery with good grace,
And solemn gesture ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: O my young worshipful m. you have parted from a dear father, a wise and provident father.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Art thou grown an ass now?

sp.speaker: Bead.
sp.p: Such an honest father ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Prithee beadle leave thy lying, I am scarce able to endure thee i'faith, what honesty didst thou ere know by my father speak, rule your tongue beadle lest I make you prove it, and then I know what will become of you, 'tis the scurvy scurviest thing i'th earth to belie the dead so, and he's a beastly son and heir that will stand by, and hear his father belied to his face, he will ne'er prosper I warrant him, troth if I be not ashamed to go to church with him, I would I might be hanged, I fear such filthy tales go on him, o
if I had known he had been such a lewd fellow in his life he should ne'er have kept me company.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O ‚Äî oh ‚Äî oh!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But I am glad he's gone, though 'twere long first, Shortyard and I will revel it i'faith, I have made him my rent-gatherer already.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He shall be speedily disinherited, he gets not a foot, not the crown of a molehill, I'll sooner make a courtier my heir for teaching my wife tricks than thee, my most neglectful son? O now the corse, I shall observe yet farther.

div.stage: A counterfeit corpse brought in, Tomazin, and all the mourners equally counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O my most modest, virtuous and remembering wife, she shall have all when I die, she shall have all.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Master Easie? 'tis, o what shift shall I make now? o ‚Äî

div.stage: Falls down in a feigned swoon.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Sweet wife she swoons, I'll let her alone, I'll have no mercy at this time, I'll not see her, I'll follow the corse.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: The devil grind thy bones, thou cozening rascal.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Give her a little more air, tilt up her head, comfort thyself good widow, do not fall like a beast for a husband, there's more than we can well tell where to put 'em, good soul.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O, I shall be well anon.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Fie, you have no patience i'faith, I have buried four husbands, and never offered 'em such abuse.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Cousin, how do you?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Sorry to see you ill coz.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: The worst is past I hope.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I hope so to.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Lend me your hand sweet coz I have troubled you

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: No trouble indeed forsooth ‚Äî good cousin have a care of her, comfort her up as much as you can, and all little enough I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Tomaz.
sp.p: My most sweet love.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: My life is not so dear.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I have always pitied you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: You've shown it here. And given the desperate hope?

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Delay not now, you've understood my love, I have a priest ready, this is the fittest season, no eye offends us, let this kiss restore thee to more wealth, me to more bliss.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: The angels have provided for me.

div.head: Incipit quintus et ultimus.
div.stage: Enter Shortyard with writings, having cozened Sim Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.l: I have not scope enough within my breast,
To keep my joys contained: I'm Quomodo's
Heir: the lands assurances, and all are mine
(I have tripped his son's heels up) above the ground,
His father left him: had I not encouragement?
Do not I know what proves the fathers pray?
The son ne'er looks on't, but it melts away.
Do not I know the wealth that's got by fraud?
Slaves share it like the riches of a bawd.
Why 'tis a curse unquenchable, ne'er cools.
Knaves still commit their consciences to fools:
And they betray who owed 'em, here's all the bonds,
All Easie's writings, let me see:

div.stage: Enter Quomodo's wife married to Easy.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now my desires wear crowns.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: My joys exceed, man is ne'er healthful, till his follies bleed.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: O, behold the villain, who in all those shapes confounded your estate.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: That slave, that villain.

sp.speaker: Short.
sp.p: So many acres of good meadow ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I hear you sir.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Rogue, Shortyard, Blastfield, sergeant, deputy, cozener

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I thirst the execution of his ears.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Hate you that office,

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'll strip him bare for punishment and shame.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Why do but hear me sir, you will not think what I have done for you.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Given his son my lands.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Why look you, 'tis not so, your not told true,
I have cozened him again merely for you,
Merely for you sir, 'twas my meaning then
That you should wed her, and have all again.
sp.p: A my troth it's true sir: look you then here sir, you shall not miss a little scroll sir, pray sir, let not the city know me for a knave, there be richer men would envy my preferment if I should be known before 'em.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.l: Villain, my hate to more revenge is drawn,
When slaves are found, 'tis their base art to fawn,
Within there ‚Äî.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: How now? fresh warders.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: This is the other, bind him fast, have I found you master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: This is the fruit of craft,
Like him that shoots up high, looks for the shaft
And finds it in his forehead, so does hit
The arrow of our fate, wit destroys wit:
The head the body's bane, and his own bears,
You ha' corn enough, you need not reap mine ears,
Sweet master Blastfield.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I loathe his voice, away.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: What happiness was here, but are you sure you have all?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I hope so my sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What difference there is in husbands, not only in one thing, but in all.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Here's good deeds and bad deeds, the writings that keep my lands to me, and the bonds that gave it away from me.
sp.l: These my good deeds shall to more safety turn,
And these my bad have their deserts and burn.
I'll see thee again presently, read there.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Did he want all, who would not love his care?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What a wife hast thou Ephestian ‚Äî Quomodo, so loving so mindful of her duty not only seen to weep but known to swoon, I knew a widow about saint Antling's so forgetful of her first husband, that she married again within the twelvemonth, nay some by‚Äôr lady within the month: there were sights to be seen, had they my wife's true sorrows seven nor seven years would draw 'em to the stake, I would most tradesmen had such a wife as I, they hope they have, we must all hope the best: thus in her honour.

div.l: A modest wife is such a jewel,
He that's honest, and not cruel,
Is the likeliest man to owe it.
div.p: And that's I, I made it by myself, and coming to her as a beadle for my reward this morning, I'll see how she takes my death next her heart.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Now beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Bless your mistress-ship's eyes from too many tears, although you have lost a wise and worshipful gentleman.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You come for your due beadle, here ith' house.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Most certain, the hospital money and mine own poor forty pence.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: I must crave a discharge from you beadle.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Call your man, I'll heartily see my hand to a memorandum.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: You deal the truel year.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Good wench still.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: George, here is the beadle come for his money, draw a memorandum that he has received all his due he can claim here ith' house after this funeral.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p:
What politic directions she gives him, all to secure herself, 'tis time i'faith now to pity her, I'll discover myself to her ere I go, but came it off with some lively jest now, that were admirable: I have it? after the memorandum is written and all, I'll set my own name to't Ephestian Quomodo,
she'll start, she'll wonder how Ephest ‚ñ™ Quomodo came hither that was buried yesterday: you're beset little Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nineteen, twenty five pound, 1, 2, 3, and 4. d.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: So, we shall have good sport, when 'tis read:

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: How now lady, paying away money so fast?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The beadle's due here sir

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Whose? 'tis easy, what makes Easie in my house, he is not my wives over seer I hope:

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: What's here?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He makes me sweat.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Memorandum that I have received of Richard Easie, all my due I can claim here i'th house ‚ñ™ or any hereafter for me: in witness whereof, I have set to mine own hand, Ephestian qommodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: What have I done? was I mad?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Ephestian Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ay, well, what then sir? get you out of my house, first you master prodigal had land, away.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What is the beadle drunk or mad? Where are my men to thrust him out a doors.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not so good Tomazin not so.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: This fellow must be whipped.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Thank you good wife.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I can no longer bear him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay sweet husband.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Husband I me undone, beggared, cozened, confounded for ever: married already? will it please you know me now mistress harlot, and master Horner, who am I now?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O, he's as like my tother husband as can be.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: I'll have judgement, I'll bring you before a judge, you shall feel wife whether my flesh be dead or no, I'll tickle you i'faith, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: The judge that he'll solicit knows me well.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Let's on then, and our grievances first tell.

div.stage: Enter Lethe with officers, taken with his harlot.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: Here they come.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: O where.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.l: Heart of shame, upon my wedding morning so disgraced ‚ñ™
have you so little conscience officers,
You will not take a bribe?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Master Lethe we may lie together lawfully hereafter, for we are coupled together before people enough i'faith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.p: There goes the strumpet.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.l: Pardon my wilful blindness and enjoy me.
For now the difference appears too plain,
Betwixt a base slave and a true gentleman.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: I do embrace thee in the best of love,
How soon affections fail, how soon they prove.

div.stage: Enter judge, Easy, and Tomazin in talk with him.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: His cozenages are odious, he the plaintiff,
Not only framed deceitful in his life,
But so to mock his funeral.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.l: Most just.
The livery all assembled, mourning weeds,
Throughout his house e'en down to his last servant
The herald richly hired to lend him arms,
Feigned from his ancestors, which I dare swear knew no
Other arms but those they laboured with,
All preparations furnished, nothing wanted
Save that which was the cause of all, his death,
If he be living.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: 'Twas an impious part.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.l: We are not certain yet it is himself,
But some false spirit that assumes his shape,
And seeks still to deceive me.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O are you come? my lord? their here, good morrow Tomazin.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: Now what are you?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I am Quomodo my lord, and this my wife,
Those my two men, that are bound wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: How are we sure you're he?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O you cannot miss my lord.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: I'll try you. Are you the man that lived the famous cozener?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O no my lord.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Did you deceive this gentleman of his right,
and laid nets o'er his land?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Not I my lord.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Then you're not Quomodo but a counterfeit,
Lay hands on him, and bear him to the whip.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Stay, stay a little I pray, now I remember me my lord, I cozened him indeed, 'tis wondrous true.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Then I dare swear this is no counterfeit.
Let all doubts cease this man is Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Why la you now, you would not believe this, I am found what I am.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: But setting these thy odious shifts apart,
Why did that thought profane, enter thy breast,
To mock the world with thy supposed death?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Conceive you not that my lord? A policy.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: For having gotten the lands I thirsted still,
To know what fate would follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Ju‚óè
sp.p: Being ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Your lordship apprehends me.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: I think I shall anon.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: And thereupon,
I out of policy possessed my son,
Which since I have found lewd, and now intend
To disinherit him for ever,
Not only this was in my death set down,
But thereby a firm trial of my wife,
Her constant sorrows, her remembring virtues,
All which are dews, the shine of a next morning dries 'em up all I see't.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Did you profess wise cozenage, and would dare
To put a woman to her two days' choice,
When of a minute does it?

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: Less, a moment
The twinkling of an eye, a glimpse, scarce something does it,
Your lordship yet will grant she is my wife.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: After some penance, and the dues of law
I must acknowledge that.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: I scarce like
Those dues of law.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.l: My lord, although the law too gently lot his wife,
The wealth he left behind he cannot challenge.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Behold his hand against it.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: He does devise all means to make me mad, that I may no more lie with my wife in perfect memory, I know't but yet the lands will maintain me in my wits: the land will do so much for me.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: In witness whereof I have set to mine own hand,
Ephestian Quomodo.
'Tis firm enough your own sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: A jest my lord, I did I knew not what.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: It should seem so, deceit is her own foe
Craftily gets, and childishly let's go.
But yet the lands are his.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Ay, warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: No my good lord, the lands know the right heir, I am their master once more.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Have you the lands?

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: Yes truly I praise heaven.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Is this good dealing? are there such consciences abroad, how? which way could he come by 'em?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My lord I'll quickly resolve you that it comes to me
This cozener whom too long I called my patron,
To my thought dying, and the fool his son
Possessed of all, which my brain partly sweat for,
I held it my best virtue, by a plot
To get from him what for him was ill got.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: O beastly Shortyard!

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: When no sooner mine,
But I was glad more quickly to resign.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.p: Craft once discovered shows her abject line.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: He hits me everywhere , for craft once known,
Does teach fools wit, leaves the deceiver none.
My deeds have cleft me, cleft me.

div.stage: Enter officers with Lethe and the harlot.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Room there.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.l: A little yet to raise my spirit.
Here master Lethe comes to wed my daughter.
That's all the joy is left me: ha? who's this?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: What crimes have those brought forth?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The shame of lust,
Most viciously on this his wedding morning,
This man was seized in shame with that bold strumpet.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Why, 'tis she he means to marry.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: No in truth.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.l: In truth you do.
Who for his wife his harlot doth prefer,
Good reason 'tis, that he should marry her.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I crave it on my knees, such was his vow at first,

sp.speaker: Pandar
sp.l: I'll say so too
And work out mine own safety,
Such was his vow at first, indeed my lord,
Howe'er his mood has changed him?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O vild slave!

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He says it true my lord,

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Rest content,
He shall both marry and taste punishment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O intolerable! I beseech your good lordship if I must have an outward punishment, let me not marry an inward, whose lasts will ne'er out, but grow worse and worse: I have a wife stays for me this morning with seven hundred pound in her purse, let me be speedily whipped and be gone, I beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He speaks no truth my lord, behold the virgin,
Wife to a well esteemed gentleman,
Loathing the sin he follows.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: I was betrayed, yes faith.

sp.speaker: Rer.
sp.l: His own mother my lord,
Which he confessed through ignorance, and disdain,
His name so changed to abuse the world and her.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
Marry a harlot, why not? 'tis an honest man's fortune,
I pray did not one of my countrymen marry my sister? why well then, if none should be married but those that are honest where should a man seek a wife after Christmas? I pity that gentleman, that has nine daughters to bestow, and seven of 'em seeded already, they will be good stuff by that time, I do beseech your lordship to remove the punishment, I am content to marry her.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: There's no removing of your punishment.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: O good my lord.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.l: Unless one here assembled
Whom you have most unnaturally abused , beget your pardon.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.l: Who should that be?
Or who would do't, that has been so abused?
A troublesome penance ‚Äî sir.

sp.speaker: Quo.
sp.p: Knave in your face, leave your mocking, Andrew, marry your Queen and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Master Easie.

sp.speaker: Easy
sp.p: I'm sorry you take such a bad course sir.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Master Quomodo.

sp.speaker: Toma.
sp.p: Inquire my right name again next time, now go your ways like an ass as you came.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Mass I forget my mother all this while, I'll make her do't at first, pray mother your blessing for once.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Callest me mother? out, I defy thee slave.

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: Call me slave as much as you will, but do not shame me now, let the world know you are my mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Let me not have this villain put upon me I beseech your lordship.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: He's justly cursed, she loathes to know him now,
Whom he before did as much loath to know,
Wilt thou believe me woman?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: That's soon done.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: Then know him for a villain, 'tis thy son,

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Art thou Andrew my wicked son Andrew?

sp.speaker: Leth.
sp.p: You would not believe me mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p:
How art thou changed? Is this suit fit for thee? A tooth-drawer's son,
this country has e'en spoiled thee since thou camest hither, thy manners better than thy clothes, but now whole clothes and ragged manners, it may well be said that truth goes naked, for when thou hadst scarce a shirt thou hadst more truth about thee.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: Thou art thine own affliction Quomodo:
Shortyard we banish, 'tis our pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Hence forth no woman shall complain for measure.

sp.speaker: Judge
sp.l: And that all error from our works may stand,
We banish Falslight evermore the land.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
